qas.question: What Old Germanic term was used to describe the non-Romance languages that developed in Europe?
What language was used for writing and by the Catholic Church instead of the language "of the people"?
The word "theudisk" was first found in a text from what year?
What year were the Oaths of Strasbourg written?
What word was used in the Oaths of Strasbourg for the oath's Germanic section?

context: The Dutch language has been known under a variety of names. In Middle Dutch, which was a collection of dialects, dietsc was used in Flanders and Brabant, while diets or duutsc was in use in the Northern Netherlands. It derived from the Old Germanic word <a0_0>theudisk<a0_0/>, one of the first names ever used for the non-Romance languages of Western Europe, meaning (pertaining to the language) of the people, that is, the native Germanic language. The term was used as opposed to <a1_0>Latin<a1_0/>, the non-native language of writing and the Catholic Church. In the first text in which it is found, dating from <a2_0>784<a2_0/>, it refers to the Germanic dialects of Britain. In the Oaths of Strasbourg (<a3_0>842<a3_0/>) it appeared as <a4_0>teudisca<a4_0/> to refer to the Germanic (Rhenish Franconian) portion of the oath.
